document.docAuthor: Qiu, Jian-Yue, Xu, Hao & Chen, Li
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic review of the Oriental flower beetle Coilodera penicillata species complex (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Cetoniinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic review of the Oriental flower beetle Coilodera penicillata species complex (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Cetoniinae)

bibRefCitation.author: Hope
bibRefCitation.refString: Hope, F. W. (1831) Synopsis of the new species of Nepal insects in the collection of Major General Hardwicke. Zoological Miscellany, 1, 21 - 32.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Macronota penicillata (Hope)
:
Harold 1869 : 1298
;
Gestro 1891 : 843
(Bhamo, northeastern Myanmar );
Arrow 1910 : 44
(northeastern India ; Keren Hills, Myanmar ).

Macronota dives
(nec Gory & Percheron):
Schaum 1844 : 367
;
Schaum 1845 : 43
;
Schaum 1848 : 27
. (misapplication of the name)

subSubSection.paragraph: Variation. Body length 18.5–22.4 mm; width 8.8–10.8 mm. Sutural maculae and anteapical maculae occasionally connected in some individuals from western Yunnan , China ( Fig. 22 ). Posthumeral maculae sometimes absent ( Figs. 21, 23 ). Most individuals have arrow-shaped tomentose area on their scutellum ( Figs. 21– 22 , 52–53 ), but that of the four individuals from Mount Daweishan ( Yunnan , China ) and central Vietnam is almost glabrous ( Figs. 23 , 54–56 ). A Chinese specimen from western Yunnan is setiferous along the mesometasternal suture ( Fig. 64 ).

Type material.
The type series cannot be located, and are perhaps lost ( Arrow 1910 ).

Other material examined (63♂♂, 109♀♀).

Distribution. China : Xizang ( new record ), Yunnan ; Vietnam ; Laos ; northern Thailand ; northern Myanmar ; northeastern India ; Nepal .

Natural history. This species usually inhabit the mountainous area at elevations of 1,000–2,500 m . The label data indicated that the adult activity from May to August. This species overwinter as mature larvae or newly emerged adults: some fresh adults were found in September 2014 (Mr. Zi-Chun Xiong, by artificial breeding), and many larvae with a fresh adult were captured in decayed wood in February 2016 within the cockroach galleries of
Salgunea raggei Roth, 1979
( Blattodea : Blaberidae : Panesthiinae ) ( Figs. 98–99 ), or Passalidae ( Fig. 102 ).

Remarks.
Coilodera penicillata
is similar to both
C. nigroscutellaris
and
C. formosana
, but the scutellum of the latter two species are glabrous (scutellum usually tomentose in
C. penicillata
), and the distal maculae and sutural maculae on the elytra of
C. formosana
always connected (those of the former two species unconnected). These diagnostic characters were adopted when Mikšić (1972) revised the genus, but the latter two were recognized as two subspecies of
C. penicillata
, and this treatment was widely accepted ( Mikšić 1976 ;
Miyake et al. 1991
; Krajčík 1998 , 2011 , 2012 ; Sakai & Nagai 1998 ;
Yu et al. 1998
; Smetana 2006; Bezděk 2016 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 21–33. Habitus of
Coilodera
. 21–24,
C. penicillata
(male): 21 & 24, Hua Phan, northeastern Laos; 22, Yunxian, Yunnan; 23, Mount Daweishan, Yunnan. 25–28,
C. formosana
: 25 & 28, Nantou, Taiwan (male); 26, Taitung, Taiwan (female); 27, Taitung, Taiwan (male). 29–33,
C. nigroscutellaris
: 29, Mount Dayaoshan, Guangxi (male); 30, Mount Wuzhishan, Hainan Island (female); 31, Mount Wuyishan, Fujian (female); 32, Mount Shengtangshan, Guangxi (male); 33, Mount Maoershan, Guangxi (male).

subSubSection.paragraph:
The character of distal maculae connecting with sutural maculae appears in all three species discussed above ( Figs. 22, 25–26, 30 ), but the differences of the scutellum, the mesometasternal suture, and the parameres are evident and consistent. Consequently, we regarded them as three independent species: scutellum usually clad with arrow-shape yellow tomentum in
C. penicillata
( Figs. 21–22 ) (except for a few individuals, see variation above), while glabrous in
C. nigroscutellaris
( Figs. 29–31 ) and
C. formosana
( Figs. 25–26 ); mesometasternal suture not engraved in
C. penicillata
( Figs. 63–64 ) and
C. nigroscutellaris
( Fig. 66 ), while deeply engraved in
C. formosana
( Fig. 65 ); parameres and basal piece distinctly different between the three species as showed in Figs. 79–84 .

The distribution of
Coilodera penicillata
ranges from Nepal and northeastern India to northern Vietnam ( Arrow 1910 ; Mikšić 1972 ; Nakane 1972 ; Sakai & Ikeda 1996 ; Krajčík 1998 , 2012 ; Sakai & Nagai 1998 ; Sakai 2008 ; Bezděk 2016 ), and the record from Yunnan , China was reported by Ma (1987) .
Coilodera nigroscutellaris
occurs in northern Vietnam and southern China and
C. formosana
is endemic to Taiwan Island ( Fig. 85 ).
